eadheader.eadid: PUBLIC "-//American Philosophical Society//TEXT (US::PPAmP::Ms Coll 61::Eugene Van Cleef Papers)//EN" "vancleef.xml"

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2013-09-13T20:53-0400

did.abstract:
A geographer from Ohio State University, Eugene Van Cleef was a specialist on Finns and Finnish immigrants to the United States, on the applications of geography to foreign trade and international commerce, and a pioneer in urban geography.
The Van Cleef Papers contain 5 linear feet of personal and professional correspondence and other materials reflecting Van Cleef's varied interests in applied geography, foreign trade, and Finns. Of particular note is an autobiographical manuscript, discussing the intellectual origins of his interests in geography and giving a concise perspective on his views of the discipline.

bibliography.head: Bibliography
bibliography.bibref: The Printed Materials department has a copy of one article by Van Cleef, "The Finns in Ohio," Ohio Archaeological and Historical Quarterly 43 (1934), 452-460. Call no. 977.1 Oh3.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of S. Earl Brown, Professor Emeritus of Geography, Ohio State, 1989 (accn. no. 1989-596ms).

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation note
prefercite.p: Cite as: Eugene Van Cleef Papers, American Philosophical Society.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Van Cleef Papers contain 5 linear feet of personal and professional correspondence and other materials reflecting the research interests of Eugene Van Cleef in applied geography, foreign trade, and Finns in America. Of particular note is an autobiographical manuscript, discussing the intellectual origins of his interests in geography and giving a concise perspective on his views of the discipline.

The Van Cleef Papers are arranged in six series:
Series I. Correspondence 1909-1973 3.5 linear feet
Series II. Manuscripts
0.5 linear feet
Series III. Travel Notes and Diaries 1906-1962 0.5 linear feet
Series IV. Subject files
0.1 linear feet
Series V. Autobiographical and biographical material ca.1913-1985 0.2 linear feet
Series VI. Publication reviews 1929-1963 0.2 linear feet

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: An applied geographer from Ohio State University, Eugene Van Cleef came to his field by way of an earlier interest in meteorology. Born in Chicago in 1887, Van Cleef received his bachelor's degree in climatology at the University of Chicago in 1908 and spent much of his early career moving between positions in the corporate world and academia. After three years at Rand McNally surveying academic institutions for their interests in wall maps, he taught geography at the State Teachers College in Duluth, Minnesota from 1911-1918. In Duluth, he began to develop the first of his career constants, an interest in Finnish immigrants in the United States, and he began to develop valuable professional contacts in geography. Among the most important colleagues he cultivated at this time was the great geographer Joseph Partsch, with whom Van Cleef studied in Leipzig in 1913-1914.

During a return to the corporate world after the First World War working for his family's chemical product firm, Van Cleef acquired the second of his career constants: an interest in applying geographical knowledge to commerce and foreign trade. A talk he gave on the topic at the American Meteorological Society in December 1920 earned him an invitation to take a position as assistant professor of geography at Ohio State, where his interest in linking geography and business were well received.

Throughout his career, Van Cleef promoted the study of geography as an applied physical science, not a social science, and he assiduously sought to orient his research toward practical matters that he believed would benefit the public weal. Focusing initially on the interaction of weather, climate, and society, by the 1920s, Van Cleef's research on the Finns took on an increased momentum. He became active in a variety of humanitarian organizations focused on Finns during the 1930s, and for his efforts, he was awarded the Order of the White Rose, Commander Class II by the Finnish government.

Convinced of the need for American corporations to improve their knowledge of the world, his department asked Van Cleef to develop a geographical curriculum in international trade. His two books on the subject, Getting into Foreign Trade (1946) and Geography for the Business Man (1943), were relatively little read, but were generally useful at increasing interest within the business community in geographical issues. His high school textbook This Business World (1937; later renamed Global Geography) was more widely used.

Perhaps the most important area of interest for Van Cleef, however, was urban geography where once again he applied his interests in commerce. Based upon a course he developed in urban geography (the first in the nation), Van Cleef's book Trade Centers and Trade Routes (1937) found a ready audience in business schools, and the book is credited with introducing the terms Umland and Hinterland into American geography.

Van Cleef was honored by the National Council for Geographic Education as recipient of an award for outstanding geographic writing in non-professional journals, and received the annual award from the International Trade Committee for work in foreign trade and was made the first honorary life member of the Ohio Academy of Science. The American Geographical Society's Van Cleef Medal was established in honor of Dr. Van Cleef and his wife, Frieda Miller Van Cleef for outstanding work in urban geography. He died in Columbus on November 7, 1983.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Approximately 526 folders of personal and professional correspondence. The personal correspondence is related mostly to friends and relatives, students and colleagues, but includes reactions to all aspects of Van Cleef's work. The larger portion, the professional correspondence, is related to Van Cleef's work in applied geography, and specifically to his interest in education, urban planning, foreign trade, writing, and the Finns and humanitarian matters.

The series includes some correspondence relating to Van Cleef's publications, generally listed under the name of the individual correspondent rather than the name of the publisher or institution. The folders are filed alphabetically by the name of the correspondent.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Data collected in 1972 for a study entitled "Economic relation between cities and their immediate environment." The folders in this group are also arranged alphabetically by correspondent, with a sub-caption of the city they represent.

did.unittitle: Annexation v. strangulations: A critical problem facing our cities
Comments by Eugene Van Cleef at a College of Commerce faculty meeting, November 1955
The economic relation between cities and the immediate environment of each
The impact of the St. Lawrence Seaway on land transportation in the Great Lakes Region
The mutuality of property management and city planning
The need for a scientific approach to city planning
The Open Court successor to the Junior Open Court
Our big cities are too big
A Program for geography in Cleveland
Planning as a unifying factor in cities
A proposal for a trade exhibition in Peru-Brazil
The re-birth of an old science
Signs are for the home folks
Some observations relative to M. W. Davis
Some recollections of a would-be meteorologist
This mayor needed no machine: he simply did an efficient job
A traveler looks at the Mediterranean public markets
Will this year's harvest make Germany self-sufficient?
Series III. Travel Notes and Diaries

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: 28 books, 8 packets and 3 folders containing information on the development of Eugene Van Cleef's career, his goals, personal ambitions, and beliefs, with self assessments of his progress. These also contain observations on foreign culture and economics and architecture, notations on topography, climate, and agriculture. Collectively, these provide not only a record of Eugene Van Cleef's career, but his cultural, moral, and religious attitudes.

physdesc.extent: 1 vol., lea. Bound with sheath spine
